passages.text: EQUITY: AUTOS & AUTO PARTS
Cut TP to CNY133, maintain Buy
Maintain Buy; TP cut to CNY133, implying \(16\%\) upside; still sustainable long- term growth outlook, with likely turnaround in 2026F

Considering the intensifying competition, the government's anti- involution stance and also its own strategy for 2025, BYD's 2Q25 results came in below market expectations. With no more material strategy changes likely this year, we expect BYD to focus more on its 2026E key strategy. With the lessons learned in 2025, so far, we believe BYD will be well- prepared. For FY25- 27F, we lower our shipment forecasts by \(10 - 11\%\) and top line forecasts by \(9\%\) each, while also revising down our GPM/OPM forecasts by \(2\%\) for each year, to reflect the China auto market's latest situation. As a result, our FY25- 27F earnings are \(27 - 30\%\) below our previous estimates. We now forecast BYD to achieve \(15\% /18\%\) revenue/earnings CAGRs over FY24- 27F. We cut our SOTP- based TP to CNY133 (from CNY167.66), while reaffirming Buy. Our new TP implies a 2026F P/E of 23x (EPS: CNY5.68). The stock currently trades at a 2026F P/E of 20x.

2Q results below market expectation; operating leverage worked against the name The key negative surprise for 2Q25 was its GPM of \(16.3\%\) (- 1.1pp y- y, - 3.8pp q- q) - the lowest level since 3Q22. Excluding the incentives paid to dealers, we believe operating leverage worked against BYD during the quarter, as growth of its business scale was unable to keep pace with capacity growth. Meanwhile, R&D expense grew \(71\%\) y- y/ \(8\%\) q- q, which further squeezed OPM to \(1.4\%\) (- 3.9pp y- y, - 1.9pp q- q), the lowest level, at least, of the past five years. As the second half is usually a better season for auto sales, we expect sequential improvement, with a more meaningful turnaround likely in 2026F.

Further technology/platform upgrades in 2026 to regain growth momentum in China and overseas markets, underpins sustainable long- term growth Facing challenges in 2025, so far, we believe BYD is now focusing more on its 2026E key strategy to provide attractive technology/platform upgrades in order to regain market momentum. With increasing R&D cost (incremental CNY10bn R&D expense in 1H25 y- y), we believe BYD remains the market leader, not only in terms of business scale but also on the EV technology side. Meanwhile, having invested resources, BYD enjoyed \(128\%\) y- y overseas shipments growth in 1H25. With multiple new upcoming overseas factories, its overseas expansion looks encouraging, which should help BYD achieve sustainable long- term growth.

Established in 1995 and headquartered in Shenzhen, BYD has grown to become China's leading new energy vehicle manufacturer and EV battery supplier, as well as involved in other industries including electronics and rail transit. It is listed on both the Hong Kong and Shenzhen stock exchanges.

Our TP of CNY133.00 is based on SOTP valuation method. We value BYD's auto and related products segment at CNY1,024bn based on 23x FY26F P/E multiple (15% discount comparing with BYD's historical median level while also based on 0.9x PEG during FY25F- 27F) while value BYD Electronics at CNY76.6bn based on 16x FY26E (based on Bloomberg consensus estimates) P/E multiple (0.5SDV above its historical median level), then apply an A/H share premium of 10%. Our benchmark for the stock is CS1300.

Downside risks include: (1) further intensifying market competition dynamics which may have negative impact to its margins and/or market share; (2) slower- than- expected overseas business expansion; (3) less- than- expected positive effect on demand from further upgrade of its technology platform.

From energy generation and storage to its applications, BYD is dedicated to providing zero- emission energy solutions. Its corporate mission is to make technological innovations for a sustainable society, which is guideline to perform its corporate social responsibility.

BYD reported its 1H25/2Q25 results on 29 Aug after market close. For 1H25, the company reported revenue of CNY371bn \((+23\%\) y- y, \(- 22\%\) h- h), driven by 2.1mn PV unit sales during the period \((+31\%\) y- y, \(- 20\%\) h- h). GPM was \(18.0\%\) in 1H25 (- 0.8pp y- y, - 1.8pp h- h), due mainly to fierce competition (e.g., CNY666 incentives per car paid to dealers by end- 2Q25, earlier than its practice in previous years), and also its strategy of launching its "Smart Driving Equality" campaign from early 2025, in our view. The company reported OPM of \(2.3\%\) (- 2.1pp y- y, - 3.4pp), mainly driven by increasing R&D efforts \((+51\%\) y- y, \(- 12\%\) h- h) in 1H25. Helped by foreign exchange gains of CNY3.2bn and also CNY6.4bn of other income related to government subsidies, which comes from the deferred revenue account on the balance sheet, the company delivered earnings of CNY15.5bn in 1H25 \((+14\%\) y- y, \(- 42\%\) h- h).

Looking at 2Q25 alone, revenue was CNY201bn \((+14\%\) y- y, \(+18\%\) q- q), with 1.1mn PV unit shipments delivered during the quarter \((+15\%\) y- y, \(+14\%\) q- q). 2Q25 GPM was \(16.3\%\) (- 1.1pp y- y, - 3.8pp q- q), the lowest level since 3Q22, again due to the early dealer incentives paid in 1H25 this time, as well as fierce competition. Also, due to the acceleration of R&D expenditure (up \(71\%\) y- y, \(8\%\) q- q), BYD's 2Q25 OPM was just \(1.4\%\) (- 3.9pp y- y, - 1.9pp q- q), the lowest level, at least, in the past five years. The company reported earnings of CNY6.4bn \((- 30\%\) y- y, \(- 31\%\) q- q), reflecting the challenges faced by the company during the quarter. Based on our estimates, its vehicle profit per shipment dropped sharply to below CNY5k per car, which is the lowest level of the past three years.

We believe the current business environment for BYD is driven by multiple levers, including competition dynamics, anti- involution momentum, while the key is still its own strategy of launching its "Smart Driving Equality" campaign this year. The feedback, based on the sales situation from the market, just reaffirms the consumption downgrade trend in the China auto sector. Therefore, providing smart driving capabilities alone is not good enough to attract consumers, compared with a cheaper price, especially in the mass market (below CNY200k). And, after some critical car accident events that increased customer awareness in 1H25, we see L2 ADAS functions' value contribution to car models becoming limited. Once again, price is still the most important factor for selling cars.

And, to worsen the situation further is the latest anti- involution trend, which had a negative impact to BYD, as the company cannot undertake further actions on its pricing strategies despite challenges from competitors, although it has the pricing power in the China auto market. Considering the above reasons, we believe BYD will just deliver gradual improvement for the rest of 2025F, especially in the China market. Nevertheless, given the lessons learned so far in 2025, we expect the company will be well- prepared into next year's key strategy, which is likely to be revealed post the Chinese New Year 2026. As the leader of the China EV sector, we expect the company to turnaround the entire situation in 2026F.

While the domestic market appears challenging, BYD is growing fast in overseas markets entering into 2025. The company reported overseas sales of 464k units in 1H25, and 545k units in 7M25 (+128% y- y, \(+133\%\) y- y). With BYD's second overseas factory in Brazil having started mass production in Jul- 25, and also the increasing number of its ro- ro (roll- on/roll- off) ships (eight in total as of end- Aug 25) for exports, we see further potential upside ahead in terms of overseas growth. Meanwhile, looking at local sales in some key areas, e.g., EU, BYD achieved 251% y- y growth in 7M25 for new car registrations with 58k registrations achieved so far this year, albeit from a low base, according to ACEA (European Automobile Manufacturers' Association). As we expect competition to intensify further in the China auto market, we believe BYD will take further efforts to enhance its global appearance in the next few years, which should eventually bear fruit in the long run.

Taking into account both the challenging environment in the China market, as well as the encouraging outlook for the overseas markets, we cut our PV shipment forecasts for BYD during FY25F- 27F by \(10 - 11\%\) . We now expect BYD to deliver less than 5mn unit PV sales in the China market for 2025F, based on the aforementioned reasons. For the domestic China market, we expect 3.9mn units of local sales, marking a \(3\%\) y- y improvement from 2024, while the overseas market may enjoy 1mn unit sales this year, implying \(140\%\) y- y growth. We expect shipments growth may likely re- accelerate in 2026F, post BYD launching its strategy for next year. We expect BYD to deliver 6.0mn unit sales in 2026F, with 7.0mn unit sales in 2027F.

Based on the quarterly performance, we also cut our revenue forecasts for the autos and related products segment by \(11\%\) each for FY25F- 27F, respectively, which results in a total revenue cut of \(9\%\) for each of the years. We now expect the company to record a \(15\%\) revenue CAGR over FY24- 27F.

In the backdrop of challenging competition in the China auto market, we cut our GPM forecast for the auto and related products segment by \(2\%\) each for FY25F- 27F. As a result, our overall GPM/OOM estimates for BYD for FY25F- 27F are also \(2\%\) lower than our previous estimates. On the bottom line, we revise down our earnings forecasts for FY25F- 27F by \(29\% /30\% /27\%\) , respectively. We forecast BYD to deliver an earnings CAGR of \(18\%\) over FY24- 27F.
Fig.7:BYD-Earnings forecast revisions
Source: Company data, Nomura estimates
Fig.8:BYD-Forecast revisions for revenue/margin by segment
Source: Company data, Nomura estimates

Our FY25F- 27F topline estimates are \(8 - 10\%\) below WIND consensus, as we believe that the current market situation is not conducive to BYD. On the bottom line, we are \(18 - 24\%\) below consensus, reflecting the current market situation. Although 2025 appears to be muted, we continue to believe that BYD will regain momentum, with its rebound in the China market likely into 2026F and also further expansion in overseas markets.
Fig.9:BYD-Nomura vs WIND consensus
Source: Company data, WIND, Nomura estimates

We cut our TP from CNY167.66 (taking into account bonus and capitalization stock) to CNY133 (implying \(16\%\) upside), which continues to be based on a SOTP valuation methodology. We value BYD's auto and related products segment at CNY1,024bn, based on a FY26F P/E of \(23x\) (a \(15\%\) discount compared with BYD H's historical median level, while also based on \(0.9x\) PEG during FY25F- 27F), and value BYD Electronic (285 HK) at CNY76.6bn, based on an FY26E (based on the Bloomberg consensus estimate) P/E of \(16x\) (0.5SD above its historical median level), and then apply an A/H share premium of \(10\%\) .

With the company's 2025 "Smart Driving Equality" campaign not playing the expected role for its business plan this year, we do not expect any material sentiment improvement within the remaining time of this year, while sales should grow on seasonality into 2H25 anyway. Nevertheless, as the leading EV player in the China auto market, we believe BYD should be well- prepared for next year's key strategy based on the lessons learned in 2025, and eventually turnaround the situation in 2026F. With its continuous encouraging development in the overseas market, we remain positive on BYD in the mid- long run, and expect it to further improve its position to become a top- tier OEM in the global auto market. We maintain our Buy rating, and our new TP implies a 2026F P/E of \(23x\) (EPS: CNY5.68). The stock is currently trading at a 2026F P/E of \(20x\) .
Fig.10:SOTP valuation for BYD A share

A rating of Buy', indicates that the analyst expects the stock to outperform the Benchmark over the next 12 months. A rating of Reduce', indicates that the analyst expects the stock to underperform the Benchmark over the next 12 months.
